profileText: (Brother of John Habersham and uncle of Richard W. Habersham), a Delegate from Georgia; born in Savannah, Ga., July 28, 1751; attended preparatory schools and Princeton College; became successful merchant, planter, and, with his cousin Joseph Clay, engaged in the mercantile business; member of the council of safety and the Provincial Council in 1775; major of a battalion of Georgia militiamen and subsequently a colonel in the Continental Army; Delegate to the Continental Congress in 1785; member of the convention in 1788 which ratified the Federal Constitution; mayor of the city of Savannah 1792-1793; appointed Postmaster General of the United States by President Washington in 1795 and served until 1801; president of the branch bank of the United States at Savannah, Ga., from 1802 until his death on November 17, 1815; interment in Colonial Park, Savannah, Ga.

researchRecord.name: In the Anthony Wayne papers, 1782, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Anthony Wayne to Joseph Habersham and others written on August 19, 1782. Anthony Wayne writes regarding returning some troop clothing with a receipt for "a sufficient voucher to settle the general account with Congress: at all events you can discount it with the Financier... also some spirits obtained... to be charged to the Commissary Generals department."

researchRecord.description: The papers contain a transcript of a letter book from 1789-1805 that contains copies of letters by various postmasters general, including Joseph Habersham.

researchRecord.name: 1797, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A contract written on October 5, 1797, between Joseph Habersham, Postmaster General of the United States, and David Gardner, Jr. and David Gardner III. The contract sets out terms which the Gardners will carry mail between Machias, Washington County, District of Maine, and the Passamaquoddy area.
